Award.AwardTitle: SFS: An Information and Systems Assurance Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ira A. Fulton School of Engineering at Arizona State University is supporting three cohorts of undergraduate and graduate students in Information Assurance (IA) via a Federal Cyber Service: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program.

Arizona State University has developed a strong cybersecurity curriculum with ten IA courses in computer science and engineering (CSE) and an additional six courses in other disciplines, including electrical engineering, industrial engineering, mathematics, and information systems in ASU's Business School. ASU's IA Research Center has been designated as a National Center of Academic Excellence in both Information Assurance Education (CAEIAE) and Research (CAE-R) by the National Security Agency and the Department of Homeland Security. Its main educational and research programs focus on trustworthy information systems and the quality of information being stored, processed or transmitted. The main strengths of this project include: (a) SFS students are provided with effective mentoring and support to successfully place them in Federal jobs. (b) In addition to a rigorous academic program emphasizing both theory and practice, all SFS students participate in IA research as part of their capstone projects, theses or dissertations. (c) The program promotes leadership, collaboration and communication skills of SFS scholarship recipients through their participation in community service, student organizations, collaborative projects, IA workshops and IA seminars. (d) Students gain hands-on experiences with various IA areas through ISU's state-of-the-art IA Instructional Laboratory, cloud-based virtualized IA laboratory, and IA research facilities.

The project is having an immediate impact on the Information Assurance and Computer Security capabilities of the federal workforce by providing highly qualified information technology and engineering professionals trained in information assurance. In order to help increase the diversity of IA professionals in the Federal workforce, this scholarship program is placing special emphasis on recruiting and graduating outstanding female students and members of other underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF SFS Scholarship Program had 14 students successfully completed the scholarship program and all are employed by Federal agencies. In addition, two students, who have not completed the scholarship program are currently completing their scholarships with our new NSF CyberCorp SFS Scholarship Program (1663651) starting August 2018. Among the 14 students completed the scholarship program, one was in the Ph.D. degree program, six were in the master degree program, two were in the BS/MS degree program, and five were in the BS degree program in either Computer Science or Computer System Engineering, all with Information Assurance Concentration  (now called Cybersecurity Concentration).  All these students are serving well for the Federal agencies

With this scholarship program, we have been able to attract more students and faculty members interested in information assurance and security, and received the needed resources to develop our students and faculty members, to develop a well-balanced IA educational curriculum that matches well with the human resource needs of the Federal Government and the public. During this scholarship program period, we have greatly improved and expanded our IA course offering and expanded and improved our instructional laboratory facilities to improve students’ hands-on experience and IA course projects.  Our courses have been well received by students and frequently full to classroom capacity.

Regarding our laboratory facilities, we developed the Virtual Laboratory with quite large cloud computing systems, which supports various computer network and software security courses and related projects.  We have also developed an instructional laboratory for computer and network forensics.  It included mobile forensics to understand how digital evidences can be extracted and analyzed from mobile devices. In addition, we introduced social network analysis with malware forensics. Our individual research laboratories in the IA area hosted meetings with potential scholarship candidates to attract them to apply for the NSF SFS and DoD IASP scholarship programs, and encourage them to be engaged in our IA research activities.

During this scholarship program period, we have hired four highly talented faculty members in information assurance area. During this scholarship program period, no faculty members in the IA area left or retired.  

Our faculty members in the IA area are very active in various IA conferences, journals and related activities. Specifically, our senior faculty members often play leadership roles in IA conferences and journals, such as general chair or giving keynote addresses in major international conferences in the IA or related to IA area.  More detailed information is provided in the final report.

In addition, we have had many student activities related to the scholarship program. Following are the examples: Since 2016, we have founded and led the Collegiate Cybersecurity Defense and Competition (CCDC) with a team composing of 6 undergraduate students and 2 graduate students participated in the west region CCDC. In 2016, we won the qualify as one of final 8 teams out of 24 teams and seated #8 in the west region final. In 2017, we won the qualify as one of final 8 teams out of 29 teams and seated #6 in the west region final.  In 2017, we collaborated with UC Santa Barbara to host the 2017 international Capture the Flag (iCTF). In addition to these activities, our new faculty, Yan Shoshitaishvili and Adam Doupé, along with faculty members at many universities, applied to host the DEF CON CTF, widely considered as the Olympics of CTF. More detailed information is provided in the final report.

The outreach program relevant to the scholarship program and IA education are mentioned in the final report.

We have advised the minority and community colleges to establish their IA programs, and develop IA curriculum. This will also help to further attract the talented students.

Since 2016, Arizona State University has launched the ASU Global Security Initiative. As part of this program, the Information Assurance Center has merged in the Center for Cybersecurity and Digital Forensics starting 2016. Our IA Center has been organizing its annual workshop on IA research and education since 2008, and the annual workshop was expanded to annual symposium in 2014-15.
